It is a common bug pattern to say try { ... } catch (Exception e) { something } as a shorthand for catching a number of types of exception each of whose catch blocks is identical, but this construct also accidentally catches RuntimeException as well, masking potential bugs.

A better approach is to either explicitly catch the specific exceptions that are thrown, or to explicitly catch RuntimeException exception, rethrow it, and then catch all non-Runtime Exceptions, as shown below: 
 try { ... } catch (RuntimeException e) { throw e; } catch (Exception e) { ... deal with all non-runtime exceptions ... }

children.name: RI: Class implements same interface as superclass
desc: This class declares that it implements an interface that is also implemented by a superclass. This is redundant because once a superclass implements an interface, all subclasses by default also implement this interface. It may point out that the inheritance hierarchy has changed since this class was created, and consideration should be given to the ownership of the interface's implementation.

children.name: RV: Method checks to see if result of String.indexOf is positive
desc: The method invokes String.indexOf and checks to see if the result is positive or non-positive. It is much more typical to check to see if the result is negative or non-negative. It is positive only if the substring checked for occurs at some place other than at the beginning of the String.

children.name: RV: Method discards result of readLine after checking if it is nonnull
desc: The value returned by readLine is discarded after checking to see if the return value is non-null. In almost all situations, if the result is non-null, you will want to use that non-null value. Calling readLine again will give you a different line.

children.name: RV: Remainder of hashCode could be negative
desc: This code computes a hashCode, and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the hashCode can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative.

Assuming you want to ensure that the result of your computation is nonnegative, you may need to change your code. If you know the divisor is a power of 2, you can use a bitwise and operator instead (i.e., instead of using x.hashCode()%n, use x.hashCode()&(n-1). This is probably faster than computing the remainder as well. If you don't know that the divisor is a power of 2, take the absolute value of the result of the remainder operation (i.e., use Math.abs(x.hashCode()%n)

children.name: RV: Remainder of 32-bit signed random integer
desc: This code generates a random signed integer and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the random number can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative. Be sure this is intended, and strongly consider using the Random.nextInt(int) method instead.

children.name: RV: Method ignores return value, is this OK?
desc: This code calls a method and ignores the return value. The return value is the same type as the type the method is invoked on, and from our analysis it looks like the return value might be important (e.g., like ignoring the return value of String.toLowerCase()).

children.name: SA: Double assignment of field
desc:
This method contains a double assignment of a field; e.g. 
int x,y; public void foo() { x = x = 17; }
. Assigning to a field twice is useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

children.name: SA: Double assignment of local variable
desc:
This method contains a double assignment of a local variable; e.g. 
public void foo() { int x,y; x = x = 17; }
. Assigning the same value to a variable twice is useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

children.name: SA: Self assignment of local variable
desc:
This method contains a self assignment of a local variable; e.g.

 public void foo() { int x = 3; x = x; }
Such assignments are useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

children.name: SF: Switch statement found where one case falls through to the next case
desc: This method contains a switch statement where one case branch will fall through to the next case. Usually you need to end this case with a break or return.

children.name: SF: Switch statement found where default case is missing
desc: This method contains a switch statement where default case is missing. Usually you need to provide a default case.
Because the analysis only looks at the generated bytecode, this warning can be incorrect triggered if the default case is at the end of the switch statement and doesn't end with a break statement.

children.name: ST: Write to static field from instance method
desc: This instance method writes to a static field. This is tricky to get correct if multiple instances are being manipulated, and generally bad practice.

children.name: Se: Private readResolve method not inherited by subclasses
desc: This class defines a private readResolve method. Since it is private, it won't be inherited by subclasses. This might be intentional and OK, but should be reviewed to ensure it is what is intended.

children.name: Se: Transient field of class that isn't Serializable.
desc: The field is marked as transient, but the class isn't Serializable, so marking it as transient has absolutely no effect. This may be leftover marking from a previous version of the code in which the class was transient, or it may indicate a misunderstanding of how serialization works.

children.name: TQ: Value required to have type qualifier, but marked as unknown
desc: A value is used in a way that requires it to be always be a value denoted by a type qualifier, but there is an explicit annotation stating that it is not known where the value is required to have that type qualifier. Either the usage or the annotation is incorrect.

children.name: TQ: Value required to not have type qualifier, but marked as unknown
desc: A value is used in a way that requires it to be never be a value denoted by a type qualifier, but there is an explicit annotation stating that it is not known where the value is prohibited from having that type qualifier. Either the usage or the annotation is incorrect.

children.name: UCF: Useless control flow
desc:
This method contains a useless control flow statement, where control flow continues onto the same place regardless of whether or not the branch is taken. For example, this is caused by having an empty statement block for an if statement: 
if (argv.length == 0) { /* TODO: handle this case */ }

children.name: UCF: Useless control flow to next line
desc:
This method contains a useless control flow statement in which control flow follows to the same or following line regardless of whether or not the branch is taken. Often, this is caused by inadvertently using an empty statement as the body of an if statement, e.g.: 
if (argv.length == 1); System.out.println("Hello, " + argv[0]);
.

children.name: USM: Abstract Method is already defined in implemented interface
desc: This abstract method is already defined in an interface that is implemented by this abstract class. This method can be removed, as it provides no additional value.

children.name: USM: Method superfluously delegates to parent class method
desc: This derived method merely calls the same superclass method passing in the exact parameters received. This method can be removed, as it provides no additional value.

children.name: UrF: Unread public/protected field
desc: This field is never read. The field is public or protected, so perhaps it is intended to be used with classes not seen as part of the analysis. If not, consider removing it from the class.

children.name: UuF: Unused public or protected field
desc: This field is never used. The field is public or protected, so perhaps it is intended to be used with classes not seen as part of the analysis. If not, consider removing it from the class.

children.name: UwF: Field not initialized in constructor but dereferenced without null check
desc: This field is never initialized within any constructor, and is therefore could be null after the object is constructed. Elsewhere, it is loaded and dereferenced without a null check. This could be a either an error or a questionable design, since it means a null pointer exception will be generated if that field is dereferenced before being initialized.

children.name: UwF: Unwritten public or protected field
desc: No writes were seen to this public/protected field. All reads of it will return the default value. Check for errors (should it have been initialized?), or remove it if it is useless.

children.name: XFB: Method directly allocates a specific implementation of xml interfaces
desc: This method allocates a specific implementation of an xml interface. It is preferable to use the supplied factory classes to create these objects so that the implementation can be changed at runtime. See javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory, javax.xml.parsers.SAXParserFactory, javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory, org.w3c.dom.Document.createXXXX for details.
